Name.BusinessNameLine1: ROCKY MOUNTAIN SER JOBS FOR PROGRESS INC

IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: SATISFYING COLORADO'S DIVERSE EMPLOYMENT, TRAINING AND EDUCATIONAL NEEDS. THIS STATEMENT REFLECTS RMSER'S OVERALL PROGRAM PHILOSOPHY, WHICH IS TO ASSIST THOSE INDIVIDUALS WHO FACE THE MOST SERIOUS BARRIERS TO EDUCATION AND EMPLOYMENT.
IRS990.MissionDescription: SATISFYING COLORADO'S DIVERSE EMPLOYMENT, TRAINING AND EDUCATIONAL NEEDS. THIS STATEMENT REFLECTS RMSER'S OVERALL PROGRAM PHILOSOPHY, WHICH IS TO ASSIST THOSE INDIVIDUAL WHO FACE THE MOST SERIOUS BARRIERS TO EDUCATION AND EMPLOYMENT.
IRS990.Description: The ROCKY MOUNTAIN SER WORKFORCE DIVISION PROVIDES VOCATIONAL, EDUCATIONAL AND ON THE JOB TRAINING TO LOW-INCOME ADULTS AND YOUTH, DISLOCATED WORKERS AND MIGRANT/SEASONAL FARMWORKERS.THE RMSER WORKFORCE DIVISION RECEIVES A MAJORITY OF ITS FUNDING FROM THE WORKFORCE INVESTMENT ACT (WIA), A FEDERALLY FUNDED PROGRAM DESIGNED TO INCREASE OCCUPATIONAL SKILL LEVELS OF PARTICIPANTS AND TO IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF THE AREA'S WORK-FORCE. THE OVERALL GOAL OF RMSER WORKFORCE DIVISION IS TO PROVIDE TRAINING ACTIVITIES THAT WILL GIVE PARTICIPANTS OPPORTUNITIES TO BECOME EMPLOYED IN FULL-TIME EMPLOYMENT AND TO RETAIN EMPLOYMENT FOR UP TO SIX MONTHS AFTER EXIT FROM THE PROGRAM WITH AN AVERAGE SIX MONTH EARNINGS OF $15,000 OR HIGHER.BETWEEN JULY 2009 AND JUNE 2010, RMSER PROVIDED WIA SERVICES TO 1,064 PARTICIPANTS THROUGH ITS WORKFORCE OFFICES THROUGHOUT COLORADO. SERVICES PROVIDED TO PARTICIPANTS INCLUDED CORE, INTENSIVE AND TRAINING SERVICES. CORE SERVICES INCLUDE INTAKE, ENROLLMENT, ASSESSMENT, PLANNING, COUNSELING AND TESTING OF PARTICIPANTS IN NEED.INTENSIVE SERVICES INCLUDE INDIVIDUALIZED EMPLOYMENT PLAN AND REFERRALS TO WORK. PARTICIPANTS WHO LACK WORK EXPERIENCE CAN BE PLACED INTO A WORK EXPERIENCE ACTIVITY TO GAIN JOB SKILLS NECESSARY TO COMPETE IN THE LABOR MARKET.TRAINING SERVICES INCLUDE VOCATIONAL CLASSROOM TRAINING IN WHICH THE WIA PROGRAM CAN PROVIDE FINANCIAL TUITION ASSISTANCE TO THOSE PARTICIPANTS WHO RECEIVE TRAINING AT LOCAL COMMUNITY COLLEGES OR PRIVATE INSTITUTIONS. PARTICIPANTS CAN ALSO PARTICIPATE IN ON THE JOB TRAINING WITH LOCAL EMPLOYERS AND EMPLOYERS RECEIVE REIMBURSMENT OF UP TO 50% OF THE HOURLY WAGE.THE VARYING LENGTHS OF TRAINING DAYS ARE DIRECTLY DETERMINED BY DIFFERING VOCATIONAL TRAINING REQUIREMENTS.PARTICIPANTS CAN ALSO RECEIVE SUPPORTIVE SERVICES FROM THE PROGRAMS TO ASSIST WITH TRANSPORTATION, CLOTHING, TOOLS, EQUIPMENT AND LICENSING FEES. SUPPORTIVE SERVICES ARE AVAILABLE IN ALL PHASES OF THE PROGRAM INCLUDING CORE, INTENSIVE AND TRAINING.ROCKY MOUNTAIN SER WORKFORCE DIVISION COMPETED FOR THE WORKFORCE INVESTMENT ACT FUNDS IN BOTH THE SOUTHEAST AND SOUTH CENTRAL REGIONS AND WAS AWARDED THE FUNDING BY THE COLORADO DEPARTMENT OF LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT FOR ONE YEAR TO PROVIDE WIA SERVICES IN THOSE AREAS. RMSER ALSO IS THE GRANTEE FOR THE UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT FOR THE ENTIRE STATE OF COLORADO UNDER WIA AND WAS AWARDED THE 167 NATIOANAL FARMWORKER JOBS PROGRAM GRANT AGAIN TO PROVIDE EMPLOYMENT AND TRAINING SERVICES TO MIGRANT/SEASONAL FARMWORKERS THROUGHOUT COLORADO.

Activity2.Description: PROVIDE HEADSTART FOR PRE-SCHOOL CHILDREN AND RELATED FAMILY SUPPORT ACTIVITIES.RMSER SERVED 2,726 CHILDREN FROM JULY 2009 THROUGH JUNE 2010, WITH AN AVERAGE 131 DAYS OF CARE AND INSTRUCTION PER STUDENT. THE OVERALL GOAL OF RMSER'S COLORADO HEAD START PROGRAM IS TO INCREASE THE SOCIAL AND COGNITIVE DEVELOPMENT OF CHILDREN IN LOW-INCOME FAMILIES RESULTING IN A HIGHER LEVEL OF COMPETENCE AND SCHOOL READINESS.THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES ARE IN PLACE TO ENSURE THAT THE OVERALL PROGRAM GOAL IS ACHIEVED:- IMPROVING THE SKILLS OF TEACHING STAFF IN USING CHILD OUTCOMES TO ENHANCE EARLY CHILDHOOD EDUCATION EXPERIENCES- STRENGTHENING INTRA-STAFF COMMUNICATION AMOUNGST ALL DEPARTMENTS- IMPROVING PARENT INVOLVEMENT AND PARTICIPATION IN THE PROGRAM- IMPROVING THE TRACKING OF STUDENT AND FAMILY OUTCOMES THROUGH THE USE OF PROMIS SOFTWARE- IMPROVING THE NEW EMPLOYEE ORIENTATION PROCESS AND IMPROVING STAFF KNOWLEDGE OF RMSER HEAD START- STRENGTHENING THE ONGOING MONITORING PROCEDURES UTILIZED BY MANAGERS- ENSURING INDIVIDUALIZATION ACTIVITIES ARE OCCURRING WITHIN EACH CLASSROOM THROUGH MORE FREQUENT OBSERVATIONS BY THE EDUCATION MANAGER- IMPROVING STUDENTS MEDICAL AND DENTAL TREATMENT RATES- IMPROVING THE MANAGEMENT OF FACILITIES AND TRANSPORTATION SERVICES- CONTINUING TO IMPLEMENT AND STRENGTH STUDENT TRANSPORTATION SYSTEMS- ESTABLISHING AND SUSTAINING COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIPS

OtherNonCashContributionsTable.MethodOfDeterminingRevenues: FAIR VALUE OF TEACHER ASSISTANCE HOURLY RATES

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: THE FORM 990 IS COMPLETED BY THE ORGANIZATION'S CPAS SUBSEQUENT TO THE AUDITED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS BEING APPROVED BY THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS. THE COMPLETED FORM 990 IS PROVIDED TO THE CEO AND THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS; THE CPAS REVIEW THE FORM 990 WITH THE CEO WHO THEN REVIEWS THE FORM 990 WITH THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS. CHANGES/CORRECTIONS ARE MADE BY THE CPAS BASED ON THE DIRECTION OF THE CEO AND BOARD OF DIRECTORS, IF APPLICABLE. ONCE CHANGES/CORRECTIONS HAVE BEEN COMPLETED THE FORM 990 IS REVIEWED A SECOND TIME BY THE CEO WHO THEN APPROVES THE FORM 990 ON BEHALF OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Conflict of Interest Policy Rocky Mountain SER requires that you protect Company information and avoid outside activities or relationships which do or could adversely influence your decisions or actions on the job. Conflict of interest situations, which could arise while moonlighting for a competitor of ours, should also be avoided. Other examples of conflicts in interest could be: serving as a board member or director of a competing firm, holding financial interest in a competing organization or being self-employed in an occupation which competes with Rocky Mountain SER, or ownership, partnership or personal involvement in supplier companies or distribution outlets related to company business. If you have any question whether a situation is a conflict of interest, discuss the matter with your immediate supervisor. If it remains unresolved, refer the matter to the Human Resource Director for a final determination.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Rocky Mountain SER/Jobs for Progress, Inc. Compensation Philosophy for Pay Increase Administration As Approved by to the Board of Directors in May 2008 Rocky Mountain SER/Jobs for Progress, Inc. provides a documented compensation plan with a compensation philosophy and administrative guidelines. It is our belief that the design and administration of compensation has a significant impact on job satisfaction, productivity, labor turnover and consequently the organization's mission and goals. Pay increases may be granted if determined appropriate by management and/or Board of Directors. The total and departmental amounts available for such wage increases, if any, will be determined solely by management and/or Board of Directors, based upon the company's financial condition. COMPENSATION PHILOSOPHY As a non-profit services organization, at Rocky Mountain SER/Jobs for Progress, Inc. we recognize that our employees are our most important asset, and our principal source of competitive advantage. To achieve our corporate objectives, we must attract, retain and motivate the most highly qualified and capable work force. We reward employees who demonstrate capability and produce results which support our organization's goals and objectives, within our ability to pay. We utilize performance-based pay plans, in addition to our base pay programs. These plans may vary from one job group to another. All plans are intended to reward employees who achieve and exceed targets for their formal written goals. In addition to cash compensation opportunities, Rocky Mountain SER/Jobs for Progress, Inc. provides a comprehensive benefits program which addresses our employees' health and welfare, and capital accumulation needs or concerns. All programs are contributory in nature and designed in a very flexible manner to enable employees to select the coverage most consistent with their needs and circumstances. Matching contributions by Rocky Mountain SER/Jobs for Progress, Inc. to our 401(k) plan will be contingent upon the achievement of all established financial targets. Merit will be distributed for each division in a range of 2% below expectations, 4% meets expectations, 6% exceeds expectations. Anything over 6% will need the approval of the Chief Executive Officer. PAY INCREASE GUIDELINES BY JOB GROUP ADMINISTRATION COLA (Cost-of-Living Adjustment) An across-the-board wage increase or supplemental payment designed to bring pay in line with increases in the cost of living. Rocky Mountain SER/ Jobs for Progress, Inc. conforms to Federal guidelines for annual COLAs, as follows: How is the COLA Determined? The U.S. Department of Labor calculates the change in the Consumer Price Index (CPI) for urban wage earners and clerical workers from the third quarter average of the previous year to the third quarter average for the current year. When is the COLA Paid? A merit increase may be added to base pay or provided as a lump sum. If added to base pay, a merit increase will be effective on the first business day of September 2008 retro back to July 31st RMSER Fiscal Year. Merit Increases An adjustment to an employees salary based on performance. How is Merit Pay Determined? Merit pay is the difference in individual pay based strictly on work performance and demonstrated results; employees who contribute more receive higher increases. Merit pay is based on measurable performance. Pay-for-performance or merit pay systems assume that performance can be observed and measured accurately. Rocky Mountain SER/Jobs for Progress, Inc. pays merit based on the scored results of annual performance appraisals, within an established budget, as follows: Performance Appraisals - To be conducted annually for each employee by his/her supervisor - Rates the employee on job duties, responsibilities and established performance improvement objectives. An overall rating is determined. - A pre-approved merit increase is awarded based on the overall rating. When is the Merit Increase Paid? A merit increase may be added to the base pay or provided as a lump sum. If added to base pay, a merit increase will be effective on the first business day of September retro back to July 31st RMSER Fiscal Year.. CHILDRENS SERVICES (HEAD START) COLA (Cost-of-Living Adjustment) An across-the-board wage increase or supplemental payment designed to bring pay in line with increases in the cost of living. Rocky Mountain SER/ Jobs for Progress, Inc. conforms to Federal guidelines for annual COLAs, as follows: How is the COLA Determined? The U.S. Department of Labor calculates the change in the Consumer Price Index (CPI) for urban wage earners and clerical workers from the third quarter average of the previous year to the third quarter average for the current year. When is the COLA Paid? Cost-of-Living Adjustments are effective each December first. The adjustment appears in your payment on the first business day of January. Merit Increases An adjustment to an employee's salary based on performance. How is Merit Pay Determined? Merit pay is the difference in individual pay based strictly on work performance and demonstrated results; employees who contribute more receive higher increases. Merit pay is based on measurable performance. Pay-for-performance or merit pay systems assume that performance can be observed and measured accurately. Rocky Mountain SER/Jobs for Progress, Inc. pays merit based on the scored results of annual performance appraisals, within an established budget, as follows: Performance Appraisals - To be conducted annually for each employee by his/her supervisor - Rates the employee on job duties, responsibilities and established performance improvement objectives. An overall rating is determined. - A pre-approved merit increase is awarded based on the overall rating. When is the Merit Increase Paid? A merit increase may be added to base pay or provided as a lump sum. If added to base pay, a merit increase will be effective on the first business day of September. WORKFORCE COLA (Cost-of-Living Adjustment) An across-the-board wage increase or supplemental payment designed to bring pay in line with increases in the cost of living. Rocky Mountain SER/ Jobs for Progress, Inc. conforms to Federal guidelines for annual COLAs, as follows: How is the COLA Determined? The U.S. Department of Labor calculates the change in the Consumer Price Index (CPI) for urban wage earners and clerical workers from the third quarter average of the previous year to the third quarter average for the current year. When is the COLA Paid? Cost-of-Living Adjustments are effective each December first. The adjustment appears in your payment on the first business day of January. Merit Increases An adjustment to an employee's salary based on performance. How is Merit Pay Determined? Merit pay is the difference in individual pay based strictly on work performance and demonstrated results; employees who contribute more receive higher increases. Merit pay is based on measurable performance. Pay-for-performance or merit pay systems assume that performance can be observed and measured accurately. Rocky Mountain SER/Jobs for Progress, Inc. pays merit based on the scored results of annual performance appraisals, within an established budget, as follows: Performance Appraisals - To be conducted annually for each employee by his/her supervisor - Rates the employee on job duties, responsibilities and established performance improvement objectives. An overall rating is determined. - A pre-approved merit increase is awarded based on the overall rating. When is the Merit Increase Paid? A merit increase may be added to base pay or provided as a lump sum. If added to base pay, a merit increase will be effective on the first business day of September.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 18
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: RMSER FORM 990 IS AVAILABLE VIA THE ORGANIZATION AND WWW.GUIDESTAR.ORG.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: RMSER GOVERNING DOCUMENTS, CONFLICT OF INTEREST POLICY AND FINANCIAL STATEMENTS ARE AVAILABLE TO PUBLIC INSPECTION UPON REQUEST.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: PROCESS FOR OVERSEEING THE APPROVAL OF THE AUDITED FINANIAL STATEMENTS
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: THE ANNUAL AUDITED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS ARE PRESENTED BY THE CPAS TO THE FINANCE COMMITTEE. COMMENTS, SUGGESTIONS AND CHANGES ARE MADE PER THE REQUEST OF THE FINANCE COMMITTEE. UPON PRELIMINARY APPROVAL OF THE AUDITED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS BY THE FINANCE COMMITTEE THE FINANCE COMMITTEE PRESENTS THE AUDITED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS TO THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS WHO THEN MAKE FINAL APPROVAL OF THE AUDITED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS.
